The completed 1933 lacrosse
schedule has been released by Dr.
Ray Van Orman, varsity athletic
coach. Seven games, instead of the
usual eight, comprise the list.
Two out-of-town teams, Princeton and New York City College, do
not appear in the latest group of
Jay opponents, although they were
played last spring. The addition of
St. Johns, which was not included
among the scheduled past-season
tilts, brings the number of Maryland teams to be met up to five,
Army and Swarthmore filling the
remaining two dates.
Five Maryland Opponents

Miss Elizabeth Boyce, Baltimore
debutante and a brilliant member
of the Green Spring Valley set, will
be presented following the conclusion of the grand march, as the guest
of honor. The grand march will be
followed by a single dance, consisting of two numbers, in which members of the Cotillion Board, the guest
of honor and seniors only will participate. Other innovations will
distinguish the evening.

Band", the members include Glen
Gray, who wields a wicked sax; Mel
Jenssen, violinist, of Toledo, and the
leader of the group, plus many other
nationally known musicians.
The orchestra consists of one violin, four saxaphones, three trumpets, two trombones, piano, banjo,
and bass drums. Five of the boys
double up on instruments with the
clarinet and flute.

CosmicRay Lecture
Of Dr. Johnson
HeardBySigma Xi
"New Experimental Methods and
Their Contribution to the Cosmic
Ray Problem" was the topic of an
address delivered by Dr. Thomas
H. Johnson, Associate Director of
the Bartol Research Foundation,
before the Johns Hopkins Chapter,
Society of the Sigma Xi, last Monday evening.
The lecture included a historical
survey of the development of the
cosmic ray problem with a description of the various experimental
methods which have been used. Recent experiments were carried out
by Kolhorster, Regener, Compton
and Millikan.
Method Used

The most important methods used
in these experiments is that which
was employed by Bothe and Kolhorster in 1929 and is usually referred to as the Geiger and Mueller
counter. The apparatus consists
of a metal cylinder, along the axis
of which is stretched a fine wire.

Fraternity rushing season will begin at 8.30 a. m. on Wednesday,
February 8, the day on which
classes are resumed for the second
semester. Before this day, no dates
or engagements for the rushing season may be made.
The present rushing agreement
differs from previous pacts in the
fact that it does not contain the
usual penalty of twenty-five dollars.
The new pact follows:
"Rushing is hereby defined as
attempting by any means to persuade a man in his first year of
residence in the University to
join a particular specified fraternity, bidding, pledging, entertaining, dating, sponsoring an entertainment, or allowing a man not
belonging to a college fraternity
in his first year of residence to
enter a fraternity house or homes
of fraternity men."
Beginning on Thursday, February 9, 1933, a period of allotted

By RICHARD FEISE

The twenty-ninth course of lectures on the Percy Turnbull Foundation is to be given by T. S. Eliot
on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday
of nexf week.
The topic of the series is the
"Metaphysical Poets", a name given
by Dr. Johnson in derision because
of the fantastic form of Donne's
poetry and often applied to all minor
poets of the Puritan age. It includes primarily Donne, Herbert,
Waller, Denham, Cowley, Vaughn,
Davenant, Marvell, and Crashaw.
Poet, Critics

T. S. Eliot has recently returned
from England to the land of his
birth and education in order to fill
the chair of poetry for the current
year at Harvard University. His
activities abroad as a poet, critic,
editor, and publisher, together with
his conversion from republicanism
to monarchism, from agnosticism to
Anglo-Catholicism, from "modernism" to the stream in contemporary
thought called 'reactionary" makes
him a figure of extraordinary interest in certain circles.
His writings have had an influence the width of which is markedly
out of proportion to their volume—
a tribute to the power of his utterance. The few volumes of defiant
poetry published between 1920 and
1930 are perhaps more directly responsible for his fame in America
than the prose essays.
Eliot was born at St. Louis, Missouri, in 1888. His family background was that of New England
culture.
One of the legends already in existence about his boyhood is that he did not speak a word
until the age of 6 or 7, when he remarked one day to his mother that
they were living a dreadful snowstorm. He returned early to Boston, the home of his ancestors, went
to Milton and then to Harvard.

Will Hear Dr. Ashley
Of Congress Library
Frederick W. Ashley, chief assistant librarian of the Library of
Congress, will address the Friends
of the Library on "The Library of
Congress and Its Treasures", Tuesday, January 31.
Mr. Ashley will tell about some
of the interesting treasures in the
great collection, including the priceless Gutenberg Bible, and the story
of its safe arrival in Washington, in
spite of threatening difficulties. A
tea will precede this lecture.
Recent Purchases

The library has just received by
purchase from the book funds of
several departments a set of bound
volumes of The New York Times
complete for the years 1914-1929.
In a recent tabulation of the library, the following report was issued: 435,000 bound volumes; 200,000 pamphlets, and several thousand
autographed letters and other documents.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 27, 1933.

LOYOLA, MOUNTS
TOP JAY COURTMEN
IN LEAGUE TILTS
Hopkins Falls From FirstPlace Tie As Result Of
Double Defeat
As a result of two consecutive
losses administered by members of
the State Basketball League, the
Jay five has tumbled from a firstplace tie to next to last position.
Last Saturday, Loyola College,
with whom the Black and Blue team
was tied for first place, humbled
Hopkins, 35-26. On Wednesday,
Mount St. Mary's treated its home
crowd to a 36-14 win over the same
Jay five.
After watching Hopkins's excellent performance against Maryland,
the Loyola fracas turned out to be
a complete disappointment. The
Black and Blue was able to work its
plays with almost as much efficiency
against Loyola as against Maryland.
However, the shots against the
Terps were going in while those
against the Greyhounds were not.

Loyola, on the other hand, played
its usual game of mixing up long
and short shots. Most of the latter
were unsuccessful due to Hopkins's
strong defense, but Beltz and Carlin
made up for this with beautiful long
range flips.
On Wednesday the Jays were not
only missing their shots, but their
plays were mostly squashed before
Jay players could ever get near the
basket. Perhaps the Mountaineers'
court was too small for the Jays;
but, aside from this factor, the
Mounts displayed a smooth defense.

Approximately 25 students are

announced by R. N. Dempster, registrar of the Johns Hopkins University. This system of admitting
undergraduates after the winter semester was inaugurated last year.
At that time, 25 freshmen were admitted.
The courses available for the
spring term are chemistry IC, mathwriting,
ematics 1C, English

French reading,
general engineering, and engineering drawing. Engineers will have
the choice of electing military science instead of French or German
reading.

ILLUSION:

This very old illusion was invented by Indian
fakirs. The secret was unearthed in 1849 by the
great magician, Robert-Houdin. At that time, ether
had just been discovered, and little was known
about it. Houdin claimed that he had discovered
that this new anesthetic could make people light as
air. To prove it, he caused the subject to rise into
the air and float apparently suspended. He passed
a hoop around the body to show there were no
wires or supports.
EXPLANATION:

There are many, many explanations for this old
trick. One is that the girl wears a concealed harness,
which ends in a socket between her shoulder blades.
This is attached to a piston below the stage. The
piston is pushed up from below, causing her to
rise in the air. The piston is invisible, because it
is covered with mirrors which reflect surrounding
draperies, similar to the background. The magician can pass the hoop over her body because it
is cut in one place. It can be pulled apart for a
second when it passes the piston.

Another "magic show" is cigarette advertising.
One of its greatest tricks is the illusion
that cigarettes can be made miraculously
"MILD" through manufacturing methods.
THE EXPLANATION: All popular cigarettes
today are made in modern sanitary factories
with up-to-date machinery. All are heat
treated—some more intensively than others,
because raw, inferior tobaccos require

more intensive treatment than choice, ripe
tobaccos.
The real difference comes in the tobaccos
that are used. The better the tobacco, the
milder it is.
It is a fact, well known by
leaf tobacco experts, that

popular brand.

Fascism is a great new ideal,
which Italy has contributed to civilization, according to Dr. Mario
Carosi, Italian Consul at Baltimore,
in an address to the Liberal Club.
The consul stated that this was the
third great Italian contribution, as
republican and Imperial Rome had
given Europe political and cultural
unity, and medieval Rome had bestowed religious and spiritual unity.
The consul stated that the Risorgimento, or movement for Italian
liberation, had unified Italy by creating a single state from the Alps
to Sicily. Furthermore, the new regime appeared somewhat staic and
tending toward undue uniformity.
To a great number of thinkers, it
seemed to be against the noblest and
best traditions of the former states.
Giolitti, An Opportunist

One of the political leaders of
Italy during the period between the
Liberation and the World War, according to Dr. Carosi, was Giolitti,
an opportunist. Under Giolitti Italy
was living day by day, so to speak,
without due respect for the traditions of the past are regard for the
future. Nevertheless, Dr. Carosi
said, thoughtful men were already
foreseeing the great ideal which was
to carry all before it in 1922, the
year of the now famous Black Shirt
March on Rome. During the entire
period of Giolitti's administration
this great change in the minds of the
Italian people was becoming more
and more evident.
"Without faith, no nation can
ever achieve anything, but, fortunately, that faith was deeply implanted in the minds of the Italians
and the idea won a decisive and important victory, which already contained the germ of the new renovated Italy of Fascism.

of any sort between fraternity

yer asserted, in his talk on Russia,

was available, it is probable that the
Hopkins chapter of Pi Lambda Phi,
the national fraternity of which Mr.
Hays is a member, will entertain
him when he arrives here next
month to speak before the weekly
assembly.

All races ofpeople since the beginning
of time, so far as we have been able
to read, have had some kind of a pipe
and have smoked something—whether
they called it tobacco or what not.
ND since smoking a pipe is so different
from smoking a cigar or cigarette,
we made a most painstaking, scientific
study in an effort to make, if we could,
a tobacco which was suited to pipes.
We found out, first, that there was a
kind of tobacco that grew in the Blue
Grass section of Kentucky called White
Burley,and that there was a certain kind
of this tobacco which was between the
tobacco used for cigarettes and the tobacco used for chewing tobacco. It is
this tobacco which is best for pipes.
We found out that Mr. J. N.Wellman,
many years ago, made a pipe tobacco
which was very popular. But it was
never advertised and after he passed
away nothing more was heard about it.
We acquired this Wellman Method and
that is what we use in making Granger.

"New Experimental Methods and
Their Contribution to the Cosmic
Ray Problem" was the topic of an
address delivered by Dr. Thomas
H. Johnson, Associate Director of
the Bartol Research Foundation,
before the Johns Hopkins Chapter,
Society of the Sigma Xi, last Monday evening.
The lecture included a historical
survey of the development of the
cosmic ray problem with a description of the various experimental
methods which have been used. Recent experiments were carried out
by Kolhorster, Regener, Compton
and Millikan.

By RICHARD FEISE

The twenty-ninth course of lectures on the Percy Turnbull Foundation is to be given by T. S. Eliot
on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday
of nexf week.
The topic of the series is the
"Metaphysical Poets", a name given
by Dr. Johnson in derision because
of the fantastic form of Donne's
poetry and often applied to all minor
poets of the Puritan age. It includes primarily Donne, Herbert,
Waller, Denham, Cowley, Vaughn,
Davenant, Marvell, and Crashaw.
Poet, Critics

T. S. Eliot has recently returned
from England to the land of his
birth and education in order to fill
the chair of poetry for the current
year at Harvard University. His
activities abroad as a poet, critic,
editor, and publisher, together with
his conversion from republicanism
to monarchism, from agnosticism to
Anglo-Catholicism, from "modernism" to the stream in contemporary
thought called 'reactionary" makes
him a figure of extraordinary interest in certain circles.
His writings have had an influence the width of which is markedly
out of proportion to their volume—
a tribute to the power of his utterance. The few volumes of defiant
poetry published between 1920 and
1930 are perhaps more directly responsible for his fame in America
than the prose essays.
Eliot was born at St. Louis, Missouri, in 1888. His family background was that of New England
culture.
One of the legends already in existence about his boyhood is that he did not speak a word
until the age of 6 or 7, when he remarked one day to his mother that
they were living a dreadful snowstorm. He returned early to Boston, the home of his ancestors, went
to Milton and then to Harvard.

Will Hear Dr. Ashley
Of Congress Library
Frederick W. Ashley, chief assistant librarian of the Library of
Congress, will address the Friends
of the Library on "The Library of
Congress and Its Treasures", Tuesday, January 31.
Mr. Ashley will tell about some
of the interesting treasures in the
great collection, including the priceless Gutenberg Bible, and the story
of its safe arrival in Washington, in
spite of threatening difficulties. A
tea will precede this lecture.
Recent Purchases

The library has just received by
purchase from the book funds of
several departments a set of bound
volumes of The New York Times
complete for the years 1914-1929.
In a recent tabulation of the library, the following report was issued: 435,000 bound volumes; 200,000 pamphlets, and several thousand
autographed letters and other documents.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 27, 1933.

LOYOLA, MOUNTS
TOP JAY COURTMEN
IN LEAGUE TILTS
Hopkins Falls From FirstPlace Tie As Result Of
Double Defeat
As a result of two consecutive
losses administered by members of
the State Basketball League, the
Jay five has tumbled from a firstplace tie to next to last position.
Last Saturday, Loyola College,
with whom the Black and Blue team
was tied for first place, humbled
Hopkins, 35-26. On Wednesday,
Mount St. Mary's treated its home
crowd to a 36-14 win over the same
Jay five.
After watching Hopkins's excellent performance against Maryland,
the Loyola fracas turned out to be
a complete disappointment. The
Black and Blue was able to work its
plays with almost as much efficiency
against Loyola as against Maryland.
However, the shots against the
Terps were going in while those
against the Greyhounds were not.

Loyola, on the other hand, played
its usual game of mixing up long
and short shots. Most of the latter
were unsuccessful due to Hopkins's
strong defense, but Beltz and Carlin
made up for this with beautiful long
range flips.
On Wednesday the Jays were not
only missing their shots, but their
plays were mostly squashed before
Jay players could ever get near the
basket. Perhaps the Mountaineers'
court was too small for the Jays;
but, aside from this factor, the
Mounts displayed a smooth defense.

spring term are chemistry IC, mathwriting,

French reading,

the choice of electing military science instead of French or German
reading.

ILLUSION:

This very old illusion was invented by Indian
fakirs. The secret was unearthed in 1849 by the
great magician, Robert-Houdin. At that time, ether
had just been discovered, and little was known
about it. Houdin claimed that he had discovered
that this new anesthetic could make people light as
air. To prove it, he caused the subject to rise into
the air and float apparently suspended. He passed
a hoop around the body to show there were no
wires or supports.
EXPLANATION:

There are many, many explanations for this old
trick. One is that the girl wears a concealed harness,
which ends in a socket between her shoulder blades.
This is attached to a piston below the stage. The
piston is pushed up from below, causing her to
rise in the air. The piston is invisible, because it
is covered with mirrors which reflect surrounding
draperies, similar to the background. The magician can pass the hoop over her body because it
is cut in one place. It can be pulled apart for a
second when it passes the piston.

Another "magic show" is cigarette advertising.
One of its greatest tricks is the illusion
that cigarettes can be made miraculously
"MILD" through manufacturing methods.
THE EXPLANATION: All popular cigarettes
today are made in modern sanitary factories
with up-to-date machinery. All are heat
treated—some more intensively than others,
because raw, inferior tobaccos require

more intensive treatment than choice, ripe
tobaccos.
The real difference comes in the tobaccos
that are used. The better the tobacco, the
milder it is.
It is a fact, well known by
leaf tobacco experts, that
Camels are made from finer, MORE
EXPENSIVE tobaccos than any other
popular brand.

Fascism is a great new ideal,
which Italy has contributed to civilization, according to Dr. Mario
Carosi, Italian Consul at Baltimore,
in an address to the Liberal Club.
The consul stated that this was the
third great Italian contribution, as
republican and Imperial Rome had
given Europe political and cultural
unity, and medieval Rome had bestowed religious and spiritual unity.
The consul stated that the Risorgimento, or movement for Italian
liberation, had unified Italy by creating a single state from the Alps
to Sicily. Furthermore, the new regime appeared somewhat staic and
tending toward undue uniformity.
To a great number of thinkers, it
seemed to be against the noblest and
best traditions of the former states.
Giolitti, An Opportunist

One of the political leaders of
Italy during the period between the
Liberation and the World War, according to Dr. Carosi, was Giolitti,
an opportunist. Under Giolitti Italy
was living day by day, so to speak,
without due respect for the traditions of the past are regard for the
future. Nevertheless, Dr. Carosi
said, thoughtful men were already
foreseeing the great ideal which was
to carry all before it in 1922, the
year of the now famous Black Shirt
March on Rome. During the entire
period of Giolitti's administration
this great change in the minds of the
Italian people was becoming more
and more evident.
"Without faith, no nation can
ever achieve anything, but, fortunately, that faith was deeply implanted in the minds of the Italians
and the idea won a decisive and important victory, which already contained the germ of the new renovated Italy of Fascism.

All races ofpeople since the beginning
of time, so far as we have been able
to read, have had some kind of a pipe
and have smoked something—whether
they called it tobacco or what not.
ND since smoking a pipe is so different
from smoking a cigar or cigarette,
we made a most painstaking, scientific
study in an effort to make, if we could,
a tobacco which was suited to pipes.
We found out, first, that there was a
kind of tobacco that grew in the Blue
Grass section of Kentucky called White
Burley,and that there was a certain kind
of this tobacco which was between the
tobacco used for cigarettes and the tobacco used for chewing tobacco. It is
this tobacco which is best for pipes.
We found out that Mr. J. N.Wellman,
many years ago, made a pipe tobacco
which was very popular. But it was
never advertised and after he passed
away nothing more was heard about it.
We acquired this Wellman Method and
that is what we use in making Granger.
